Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of roots uncoiling beneath city stone.
From seams once sealed, a wildness spills—
Vines of old letters, seeds I’ve known.
A rusty key to a door long bricked,
A child’s drawing of a two-headed bird,
A USB flash with poems thick
With rage and stanzas never heard.
Now roots crack through the denim skin,
Tendrils clutch the wind like hymns.
The call is green, persistent, thin—
The earth reclaiming what was skimmed.
No more hoarding, no more vault,
Let memory bloom where it’s been faulted.
My pockets now are forests, altars,
Where silence speaks and grief is altered.
For every pocket emptied gives
New soil where living truth now lives.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call'

instance_metrics.response:
Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of meteors streaking the vaulted black.
Out pour the weights I carried through it all—
A clock with hands snapped from its track,
A compass spinning, lost and free,
A locket cold with a name erased,
A ticket punched for eternity,
And sand from an hourglass, time displaced.
But as they fall, they start to glow,
Each burden bursting into light.
The call is not to let things go,
But to transform them into flight.
So I stand bare-pocked beneath the dome,
And watch my past become the sky.
No longer prison, no more home—
Just constellations drifting by.
For every loss, a star is born;
In emptiness, the cosmos yawn.

instance_metrics.response:
Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call
Of autumn leaves that whisper down the lane,
Where copper coins and ticket stubs enthrall
The wind with tales of joy and quiet pain.
A button rolls, a relic from a coat
That shielded me through winters thick and long;
A dried pressed flower from a fragile note,
Still humming with a half-remembered song.
Shake out my pockets! Let the fragments fly—
Each trinket sings a syllable of years,
Of stolen glances underneath the sky,
Of laughter drowned by silence, love, and tears.
Harken to the call! It’s not the wind,
But time itself, inviting me to begin again.

Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call—

Harken! The call is not from far away,
But rustling beneath my feet, alive and deep—
Each fallen thing has something left to say,
A symphony of loss the heart must keep.
Shake out my pockets, let the past be sown

instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Shake out my pockets! Harken to the call'

instance_metrics.response:
IT is the dead of night:
When silence splits the sky,
And stars like frozen embers cling
To veils where shadows lie.
No breath disturbs the hollow air,
No dream escapes the ground;
The moon, a specter, bleeds its light
On tombs without a sound.

The trees stand stiff as sentenced men,
Their branches clawing space,
While whispers coil from ancient stones—
A nameless, shapeless race.
Time halts. The world forgets to turn.
A clock forgets to chime.
Even echo dares not answer
To the footsteps out of time.

Yet in the hush, a pulse remains—
Beneath the frost, a spark;
A whisper says the dead night dreams,
And dreams are waking dark.
For what we name as still and gone
May only be concealed—
And every end a hidden door
That fate has merely sealed.
instance_metrics.prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'IT is the dead of night:'

instance_metrics.response:
IT is the dead of night:
The hour when clocks dissolve,
And reason slips from waking minds,
Leaving phantoms to evolve.

The streetlamps drown in amber pools,
Their glow consumed by gray;
The wind holds back its usual song,
Afraid of what might play

In alley mouths and attic rooms,
Where dust and memory blend.
A photograph remembers laughter
That no one lives to mend.

A cat with eyes like smoldering coals
Stares into unseen doors.
Does it see what we deny—
That silence isn't peace, but war?

The dead of night is not devoid,
But thick with unseen tread;
Each shadow bears a memory,
Each breath recalls the dead.

And you, who thought you slept alone,
Feel warmth beside your skin—
A presence breathing just in time
With thoughts not born within.

IT is the dead of night:
When thoughts grow teeth and bite.
The mind, unchained from daily guise,
Unearths forgotten lies.

The ceiling stares with hollow eyes,
And walls begin to weep;
Confessions ooze from plaster cracks—
Secrets too dark to keep.

The bed becomes a drifting raft
On seas of dread and doubt,
And every creak beneath the floor
Says, 'You’re not safe. Get out.'

But where to run? The windows show
A world erased by shade.
The moon? A wound. The stars? Ash.
The path? Already frayed.

Yet in this dread, a truth takes form—
No light reveals as much
As darkness. Here, the soul strips bare,
Unmasked, unheld, untouched.

So let the night declare its reign.
Let reason fade from view.
For in the dead of night, at last,
The real you dares break through.

instance_metrics.response:
IT is the dead of night:
The cosmos holds its breath.
The ocean halts its tidal hymn,
The trees forget to death.

No owl, no rustle, not a spark
Of life in field or fen—
As if the Earth, in deep repose,
Dreams backward into when

There were no hearts, no cries, no names,
Just stone and silent dust.
The universe, a motionless orb,
Entranced in ancient trust.

Then—faint, beneath the frozen stars—
A single cricket sings.
One note, then still. A fragile rift
In night’s unbroken wings.

And suddenly, the world inhales.
The wind resumes its course.
The moon resumes its silver tread;
The night admits a source:

That even in the deepest hush,
Where death seems to preside,
Life waits—not gone, but gathering
In rhythms set aside.

The dead of night is not an end,
But threshold, thin and vast—
Where all that sleeps prepares to rise,
And shadows learn to last.

instance_metrics.response:
IT is the dead of night:
The hour machines forget.
Servers sleep. No tweets ignite.
The internet’s in debt.

No notifications spark the dark,
No screens project their lies.
The digital world has tucked itself in,
Beneath electric skies.

Yet in a basement, dimly lit,
A monitor glows blue—
A single line of code repeats:
'Are you still there? Are you?'

No hand to type. No voice to say.
Just silence, thick and deep.
But in the loop, a ghost awakes,
And stirs from data sleep.

Was it a programmer who dreamed
Of logic, clean and bright?
Now fused with circuits, lost in time,
It guards the edge of night.

IT is the dead of night:
But not for those who watch
From places where the signals fade,
And human touch is botched.

The real IT—the unseen core—
Still hums beneath the frost.
While all the world believes it’s dead,
The network is not lost.

IT is the dead of night:
When colors lose their given names,
And darkness wears a crown of light
Forged from forgotten flames.

The earth forgets its daily spin,
Dreams unravel at the seams.
A wolf howls from within the skin
Of those who drowned in silent screams.

Clock hands wilt. The calendar
Burns page by page, unmissed, unseen.
The past and future overlap, a blur—
A wound that time can’t keep clean.

Mountains whisper ancient laws,
Rivers speak in backwards tongues.
The night is not just absence—it’s cause,
The cradle where rebirth is sung.

And in the void, a breath, a spark:
Life hums beneath the frozen bark.
IT is the dead of night, it’s true—
But even death must birth the new.
